awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Ultrafast Electrochemical Capacitors for Electronic and Energy Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to develop an ultrafast electrochemical capacitor technology, which will act as rapidly responding energy devices for pulse signal generation and pulse energy storage in sensor and communication systems or as filtering capacitors to smooth out current ripples in electronic circuits.  The market segment of ripple current filtering is currently served by aluminum electrolyte capacitors (AECs). However, their bulky size, low capacity, polarity sensitivity and poor lifetime prevent the development of miniaturized and advanced electronic systems. In addition, due to AECs' slow response, conventional supercapacitors do not address the need for fast pulse power generation and pulsed energy storage in modern sensors and communication systems. A postdoctoral researcher, a young assistant research scientist and undergraduate students participating in this project will be trained in entrepreneurship and leadership development to accelerate the commercialization of the proposed capacitors. 

The proposed research on ultrafast capacitors is aimed at electrode nanostructure design and optimization, fabrication process development, and device characterization and testing. It is expected that addressing these technical hurdles will accelerate the commercialization of the technology. This PFI project will develop novel crosslinked carbon nanofiber sheets, which are further anchored with nanoparticles to achieve both a large electrode surface area and a reduced electrode resistance. This approach is expected to deliver large capacitance density and a high frequency response which are required to develop high-performance ultrafast electrochemical capacitors. In addition, the project is expected to enable large-scale manufacturing of nanostructured electrodes. Ultimately, this PFI project will de-risk product prototyping and translate prior NSF-funded fundamental research into marketable products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

The goal of this project was to advance ultrafast electrochemical capacitor technology for next-generation energy storage and power delivery applications, specifically in areas requiring rapid response and high-frequency energy handling, such as pulse signal generation, power conditioning, and ripple current filtering in electronic devices. Traditional aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) dominate these applications but suffer from limitations such as bulkiness, short lifespans, high equivalent series resistance (ESR), and polarity sensitivity. Our project introduced innovative materials and design approaches to produce capacitors that are significantly smaller, faster, and more reliable. These advancements were achieved through optimizing electrode nanostructures, refining fabrication processes, creating prototypes, and performing rigorous performance testing, with the long-term goal of commercializing compact, high-capacitance capacitors.

Results and Findings:

The project produced several key technical and scientific outcomes that position our capacitors as competitive alternatives to traditional AECs:

Electrode Nanostructure Innovation: We developed freestanding carbonized cellulose fiber electrodes embedded with vertically aligned MoS₂ nanoflakes, enhancing both specific capacitance and frequency response. This unique electrode configuration allowed for high capacitance density and maintained performance across a wide frequency range, addressing the needs of ripple current filtering applications and demonstrating stable operation in high-stress, high-frequency conditions. A 2nd nanostructured carbon electrode was derived from the rapid carbonization of bacterial cellulose embedded with zeolitic imidazolate framework 8 (ZIF-8) and in-situ formed carbon nanotubes. The electrode exhibited a high specific capacitance of 2.1 mF cm⁻² at 120 Hz, maintaining performance even at high frequencies. Stacking these electrodes increases capacitance to 5.3 mF cm⁻² with a slight phase degradation. Ripple voltage analysis under various loads and frequencies indicated effective filtering capabilities, highlighting the potential of these nanostructured ECs for next-generation electronic applications.

Advanced Fabrication Processes: A novel, scalable method for adjacent electrodeposition of metal-organic framework (MOF) coatings on porous separators was invented. This technique significantly improved the ionic conductivity of separators, which is critical for efficient charge transfer in high-frequency applications. The method enabled precise, uniform coating of MOFs on commercial separators, leading to capacitors with nearly doubled ionic conductivity compared to conventional designs. This process was streamlined for cost-effectiveness, further supporting the project’s commercialization goals.

Comprehensive Testing and Characterization: Our testing demonstrated the capacitors’ applicability for ripple current filtering and high-frequency power applications. They exhibited reduced area resistance, low ESR, and stable high-frequency performance, effectively outperforming traditional AECs in both stability and lifespan. The prototypes consistently displayed strong filtering capabilities and demonstrated reduced size by 5-10 times, compared to conventional capacitors, without sacrificing energy density or stability.

Prototyping and Product Development: The optimized electrode and separator technologies were integrated into capacitor prototypes suitable for various applications, including compact consumer electronics, wearable devices, and medical implants. These prototypes are now positioned for further testing in industry applications and commercialization efforts, with intellectual property protection secured.

Broader Impacts:

This project significantly contributed to training and workforce development in innovation and entrepreneurship. Four graduate students and one undergraduate student participated in the research, gaining hands-on experience in nanomaterials fabrication, electrochemical testing, and commercialization strategies. Through the NSF I-Corps program and entrepreneurial training at Arizona State University, students were trained in customer discovery, business model development, and intellectual property management. These skills prepared students for leadership roles in academia and industry, with one team member establishing a startup focused on energy storage technology after graduation. Additionally, we conducted extensive market research, interviewing over 100 potential customers, which refined our understanding of industry needs and informed our product’s development direction.

Other Outputs:

Patents: Two patent applications were filed to protect core project innovations. The first patent covers the carbonized-cellulose fiber electrode design, and the second patent addresses the adjacent electrodeposition method for MOF coatings on separators.

Publications and Conference Presentations: The project’s findings were disseminated through multiple venues. Presentations at conferences and two journal papers (one published and a 2nd one is under review) contributed to advancing scientific knowledge in electrochemical capacitor technology.

Prototype Development and Demonstration: We developed capacitor prototypes optimized for filtering applications, providing a viable solution to replace bulky AECs in size-sensitive devices. These prototypes have attracted industry interest for their ability to maintain high performance while achieving significant size reduction.

Conclusion:

The successful outcomes of this project represent a major step forward in electrochemical capacitor technology. By addressing key limitations of traditional AECs, our ultrafast capacitors offer high-frequency response, enhanced reliability, and a substantially smaller form factor, making them ideal for applications in compact, high-performance electronic devices. This research has laid the groundwork for future commercial products, with ongoing plans for additional prototype testing, industry collaborations, and market introduction. Our capacitor technology is set to impact on a range of industries, from consumer electronics to medical devices, supporting the next generation of energy-efficient, compact electronic systems.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2024
Modified by: Zhaoyang Fan
